front: What is the halting problem? How was it demonstrated?
back:
The halting problem says that it is not possible to devise an algorithm which can determine, given a program and an input, whether that program will halt or continue forever *without running the program*.
To prove it, you suppose there is such an program that can determine if another program will halt or not.
Now, create a new program, run the original program and say "if the program says it will halt, repeat forever, otherwise halt" (so do the opposite of what it says).
Now, feed the program into itself, with itself as the input. There is no possible output - if the program would repeat forever, the program would halt and vice versa - paradox, hence there is no such program. Q.E.D.

front: How can you make a state transition table for checking if a binary number is odd?
back:
State Input Next State
S0 0 S1
S0 1 S0
S1 0 S1
S1 1 S0

front: What regular expressions symbols do you need to remember? (Other symbols will be explained anyway).
back:
• * = 0 or more repeats.
  • + = 1 or more repeats.
  • ? = 0 or 1 repeats.
  • | = either or
  • () = grouped

front: What is a mealy machine?
back: A mealy machine is a finite state machine that also produces an output for each time an input is received.

back:

front: What is a context-free language?
back: A language that is not a regular language, e.g. cannot be described by a regular expression. A context-free language can be represented using Backus-Naur form.

front:
How do you convert the expression:
6 3 - 2 5 * +
Into infix?
back:
Read from left to right. Every time you meet an operator, apply it to the last two items you met. (Except unary minus which only requires one arg).
  • (6 - 3)
  • (2 * 5)
  • (6 - 3) + (2 * 5)
  • 6 - 3 + 2 * 5

front: How do you know if floating point is normalised or not?
back: A normalised floating point number will have a mantissa that starts in either 10 or 01. This is because any duplicated starting digits do not change the value of the number, and waste space in the number.

front: What different symbols are used in Backus-Naur form?
back:
• < > - anything surrounded by these is a non-terminal symbol.
  • ::= - used to create a production rule.
  • | - the 'or' symbol, either everything to the left of it or everything to the right of it, until you hit another |.

front:
Convert to denary.
MANTISSA EXPONENT
01101011 1101
back:
1. Default binary point position in the mantissa is between digit 1 and 2 - 0.1101011
  2. Look at exponent 1101 - this is -3 in denary (2s complement).
  3. Move binary point right by -3 points, duplicate the first digit as you do so.
  4. 0.0001101011
  5. Convert normally to denary.

front: How do you describe the difference between countably and uncountably infinite sets?
back:
A countably infinite set can be mapped onto the set of natural numbers ‚Ñï, for example the multiples of 3 can be counted 0, 3, 6 and so on.
An uncountably infinite set has no such mapping, for example the set of real numbers ‚Ñù - there is no way to start counting the items.

front: What is big O notation?
back: Big O notation is a measure of time complexity. It measures how well an algorithm scales with time as the size of the data set increases.

front: What does the set of {0‚Åø1‚Åø | n >= 0} actually represent?
back:
{a‚Åøb‚Åø | n >= 0} = {Œµ, ab, aabb, aaabbb, aaaabbbb, ...}
Œµ is the "empty string"

front: What is an expression tree?
back:
An expression tree is a way to describe an algebraic expression. If you traverse the tree in:
  • Pre-order = polish notation
  • In-order = infix (looks normal)
  • Post-order = reverse polish notation

front: What are the two ways to define a regular language?
back:
A regular language is either:
  • A language which can be represented by a regular expression.
  • Any language that a finite state machine will accept.

front:
How do you convert the expression:
4 * 2 + 6 - 3
Into RPN?
back:
Bracket up according to BIDMAS, then slowly create the expression by rewriting every "a.b" as "ab."
  • 4 * 2 + 6 - 3
  • (((4 * 2) + 6) - 3)
  • ((42*) + 6) - 3)
  • ((42*6+) - 3)
  • 42*6+3-

front:
Which of the following strings match the regular expression a+c+(d|e)*
  • aaccdede
  • cd
  • acd
  • aceeee
  • ac
  • acac
back:
a+c+(d|e)*
  • aaccdede - yes
  • cd - no, needs to start with at least 1 a
  • acd - yes
  • aceeee - yes
  • ac - yes
  • acac - no, after the first c there needs to be nothing or a d or an e

front: What is the difference between a terminal and non-terminal symbol in Backus-Naur?
back: A terminal symbol is one that is made of actual strings. A non-terminal symbol contains other non-terminal symbols that can be broken down further.

front:
What are the set symbols for:
  • Union
  • Intersection
  • Difference
And what does each mean?
back:
• Union - ‚à® - where A ‚à® B is the set containing elements that appear in either one of the sets.
  • Intersection - ‚àß - where A ‚àß B is the set containing the elements the sets have in common.
  • Difference - \ - where A \ B is the set of A where any items that also appear in B are removed.

front: How can you represent a finite state machine?
back:
• State Transition Diagram - a picture that uses circles and arrows
  • State Transition Table - a table for each combination of state, an input, and the next state if given that input.

front: How can you compute an RPN expression using a stack?
back:
Iterate over the expression one character at a time. If you reach a number, add it to a stack. If you reach an operator, pop the number of items that operator needs from the stack.
  • +, -, *, /, ^ = 2 operands.
  • ~ = 1 operand (unary minus)
For the dual operand operators, apply the operator so that it's like second_popped - first_popped, otherwise its wrong. Then, push result to the stack and continue. There should be one item left on the stack at the end which is your answer.

front: How would you write a set comprehension for even numbers?
back:
{x | x œµ ‚Ñï ‚àß x is even}
  • | means 'such that'
  • ‚àß means 'and'

front: What is the Cartesian product of two sets?
back:
The Cartesian product is written as A x B, this produces a new set which the set of all ordered pairs of elements:
  • for a in A:
  • for b in B:
  • new_set.append((a, b))

front: What is a set?
back: A set is a well defined collection of objects.

front:
What are each of these common sets:
  • ‚Ñï
  • ‚Ñ§
  • ‚Ñ§+
  • ‚Ñ§0+
  • ‚Ñö
  • ‚Ñù
  • ùïÄ
  • ‚ÑÇ
  • ‚àÖ
back:
• ‚Ñï - natural numbers
  • ‚Ñ§ - integers
  • ‚Ñ§+ - positive integers
  • ‚Ñ§0+ - positive integers and 0
  • ‚Ñö - rational numbers
  • ‚Ñù - irrational numbers
  • ùïÄ - imaginary numbers
  • ‚ÑÇ - complex numbers
  • ‚àÖ - empty set

front: What is the definition of a tractable and an intractable problem?
back:
A tractable problem is one that *can be solved* using an algorithm that has a polynomial time complexity or better.
An intractable problem is one that *can be solved* with an algorithm of exponential time complexity or worse.

front: What is a production rule in Backus-Naur, and how do you write one?
back:
A production rule in Backus-Naur is a rule which states how non-terminal symbols can be contructed from terminal and non-terminal symbols.
They can be written like:<number> ::= <digit>|<digit><number>

front: What is the difference between a subset and a proper subset? What are the symbols for both?
back:
A proper subset means that all of a set's elements are contained within another set, for example:
{0, 1, 2} ‚äÇ {0, 1, 2, 3} (proper subset)
A subset differs because a subset allows for the sets to be identical while a proper subset does not.
{0, 1, 2, 3} ‚äÜ {0, 1, 2, 3} (subset)

front: How do you typically denote a set?
back:
• Capital letter
  • Surround items in '{}'
  • Comma to separate items
For exampleS = {a, b, c, d}

front: What are the different time complexities you need to know for A-Level? (Ranked best to worst).
back:
• O(1) - constant time complexity.
  • O(logn) - logarithmic time complexity.
  • O(n) - linear time complexity.
  • O(nlogn) - linearithmic time complexity.
  • O(n¬≤) - polynomial time complexity.
  • O(a‚Åø) - exponential time complexity.
  • O(n!) - factorial time complexity.

front: What is the definition of a computable problem?
back: A problem can be defined as computable if there is an algorithm that can solve every instance of this problem in a finite number of steps.

front: What is symmetric difference of a set?
back: The symmetric difference of a set is all elements of both sets except the elements that appear in both. It is written as (A \ B) ‚à® (B \ A).

front: What is the cardinality of a set?
back: The cardinality of a set is the number of elements it has. Only finite sets have a cardinality.

front: Convert 13.25 to floating point binary, using an 8 bit mantissa and a 4 bit exponent.
back:
1. Convert normally to binary, using the smallest amount of bits you can - 1011.01
  2. Remember this is twos complement, so it needs a leading 0 - 01011.01
  3. Pad the end of the number with zeros until you fill the mantissa - 01011.010
  4. Shift binary point and count how far it moved to the left (if going right, its negative)
  5. 0.1011010 = 4 places left.
  6. 4 in binary = 0100 (4 bit exponent).
  7. So 13.25 = 01011010 0100.

front: How can you have floating point binary?
back: Have a bunch of bits. Define some of the bits to be your mantissa, and some of the bits to be your exponent. To find the actual value, bitshift your mantissa by your exponent.
